a machine readable transcription

availability.p: The text of the original document is in the public domain. Subject to certain exceptions, public domain works may be freely copied or used in the creation of derivative works without permission, or authorization, of the former copyright owners.

The text encoding was created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and is governed by a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

note.p: This is a Ddaft of "Old Chants," made of fragments pasted together, with corrections in Whitman's hand, which includes on the page a note by Horace Traubel reading "Given by Walt Whitman to me and then by me to Will Innes, 1905." The verso reads: "Henry Curtis printer, Cor: Bridge Ave. & 2d, Camden." "Old Chants" first appeared in Truth (19 March 1891), and was reprinted in Good-Bye My Fancy (1891).

bibl.author: Whitman, Walt
bibl.title: Old Chants
bibl.orgName: Rare Books and Manuscripts, Special Collections, Temple University Libraries, Temple University
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.

lg.l: An ancient song reciting, ending,
Once gazing toward thee, Mother of All,
Musing, seeking themes fitted for thee
Accept for me, thou saidst, the elder ballads,

l.hi: And name for me before thou goest each ancient poet.

lg.l: (Of ‸many debts incalculable,
Haply the ourNew World's chiefest debt is to the old poems.)
Ever so far back, preluding thee, America,
First Old Chants, Egyptian priests and those of Ethiopia,
The Hindu epics, the Grecian, Chinese, Persian,
The Bible books and prophets, the deeps idylls of the Nazarene,
The Iliad, Odyssey, plots, doings, wanderings of Eneas,
Hesiod, Eschylus, Sophocles, Merlin, Arthur,
The Cid, Roland at Roncesvalles, the Nibelungen,
The troubadours, minstrels, minnesingers, skalds,
Chaucer, Dante, flocks of singing birds,
The Border Minstrelsy, the bye-gone ballads, feudal tales, essays, plays,
Shakspere, Schiller, Walter Scott, Tennyson,
As some vast wondrous ‸weird dream:presences,
The great shadowy groups gathering around,
Darting their mighty masterful eyes forward at thee,
Thou! with as now thy bending neck and head, with courteous hand and word, ‸ascending,
Thou! pausing a moment, drooping thine eyes upon them, blent with their music,
Well pleased, accepting all, curiously prepared for by them,
Thou enterest at thy entrance porch.

body.note: Given by Walt Whitman to me and then by me to Will Innes, 1905.
